title: National Patriotic Coalition
text:
The National Patriotic Coalition (in <a href="Spanish%20language">Spanish</a>: "Coalición Patriótica Nacional", CPN) was a <a href="Panama">Panama</a>nian <a href="conservative">conservative</a> <a href="nationalist">nationalist</a> <a href="political%20party">political party</a>.
It was founded in advance of the election of 1952 to support the presidential aspirations of Colonel <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">José Antonio Remón Cantera</a>, head of the <a href="Military%20of%20Panama">National Police</a>.
Its six original members were the <a href="Renewal%20Party">Renewal Party</a> (PREN), <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Liberal Party “del Matadero”</a> (PL), <a href="National%20Revolutionary%20Party%20%28Panama%29">National Revolutionary Party</a> (PNR), <a href="Authentic%20Revolutionary%20Party">Authentic Revolutionary Party</a> (PRA), <a href="Popular%20Union%20Party">Popular Union Party</a> (PUP) and <a href="Patriotic%20Youth%20Front">Patriotic Youth Front</a> (FJP).
In 1953 the CPN, a coalition of several parties, was reorganized as a single party. It was the government party during <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">José Antonio Remón Cantera</a>'s presidency and continued to be one of the principal parties until the late 1960s.
The ideology of CPN was vague: it supported the developmentalist and reformist policies of the <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a> government (1952–1955), following <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a>'s assassination in 1955, supported the conservative <a href="Ricardo%20Arias%20%28politician%29">Ricardo Arias</a> government (1955–1956) and <a href="Ernesto%20de%20la%20Guardia">Ernesto de la Guardia</a> government (1956–1960), which dismantled many of <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a>'s progressive reforms, and in the early 1960s included among its deputies in the National Assembly <a href="Thelma%20King">Thelma King</a>, who for a while was one of the principal advocates of <a href="Fidel%20Castro">Castroist</a> tendencies in <a href="Panama">Panama</a>.
The CPN was the official government party from its formation in 1952 until 1960. In the 1956 elections the CPN's presidential candidate was <a href="Ernesto%20de%20la%20Guardia">Ernesto de la Guardia</a>; he polled 177,633 votes (68.49%) in the election.
Meantime, the CPN, undisturbed by any effective opposition in the National Assembly, began to suffer serious dissension within its own ranks.
<a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a> conceived of the CPN as a system whereby political power was wielded by one faction of the official party and then another. <a href="Ernesto%20de%20la%20Guardia">De la Guardia</a> abetted friction among the parties in the official coalition. He refused a cabinet post to the CPN faction of First Vice-President <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Temístocles Díaz Q.</a>. Nor was the bloc of seats in the National Assembly allowed the <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Díaz</a> faction proportionate to its electoral strength. Perhaps as a direct affront to <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Temístocles Díaz</a>, the President named <a href="Gilberto%20Arias%20Guardia">Gilberto Arias Guardia</a>, a nephew of the former President <a href="Arnulfo%20Arias">Arnulfo Arias</a>, to the cabinet. The enmity between <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Temístocles Díaz</a> and the elder <a href="Gilberto%20Arias%20Guardia">Gilberto Arias</a> was notorious. <a href="Gilberto%20Arias%20Guardia">Gilberto Arias</a>' incorporation into the cabinet did not reflect a shift in party alignments, but it neutralized the <a href="Gilberto%20Arias%20Guardia">Arias</a> news media.
Coincident with the downgrading of <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Temístocles Díaz</a> and his CPN faction was the upgrading of the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Liberal Democrata</a> group. Following <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a>'s assassination, the former <a href="Renewal%20Party">Renewal Party</a> (PREN) faction under <a href="Ricardo%20Arias%20%28politician%29">Ricardo Arias</a> guided the CPN, but when <a href="Ernesto%20de%20la%20Guardia">Ernesto de la Guardia</a> was elected president, he lured the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Liberal Democrata</a> faction and gave it dominance in the CPN.
Formerly a part of the <a href="National%20Liberal%20Party%20%28Panama%29">National Liberal Party</a>, the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Liberal Democratas</a> had opposed the <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a> regime. For having switched to the CPN after the <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a>'s death, the <a href="Liberal%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Liberal Democratas</a> were rewarded with the foreign ministry and the agriculture, commerce, and industry portfolio.
A first formal split in the CPN took place on 27 May 1957 when <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Temístocles Díaz Q.</a> with 37 prominent members, resigned from the CPN and took with him six deputies of the National Assembly of former <a href="Popular%20Union%20Party">Popular Union Party</a> and <a href="Authentic%20Revolutionary%20Party">Authentic Revolutionary Party</a>.
The reason for the split was general dissatisfaction with the president's political leadership. On 3 June 1957, <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Díaz</a> was joined in his stand by former President <a href="Alcib%C3%ADades%20Arosemena">Alcibíades Arosemena</a> and four ex-cabinet members and formed a new party named the National Liberation Movement to oppose <a href="Ernesto%20de%20la%20Guardia">de la Guardia</a>.
This was a severe blow to the political supporters of President. The formation of the <a href="National%20Liberation%20Movement%20%28Panama%29">National Liberation Movement</a> led by <a href="Tem%C3%ADstocles%20D%C3%ADaz%20Q.">Temístocles Díaz Q.</a> created additional problems for the disintegrating CPN. The <a href="Ernesto%20de%20la%20Guardia">de la Guardia</a> administration generally tended to be overwhelmed by its domestic problems and the rapid pace of events in foreign affairs.
In 1958, <a href="Aquilino%20Edgardo%20Boyd%20de%20la%20Guardia">Aquilino Boyd</a> withdrew his faction and created the <a href="Third%20Nationalist%20Party">Third Nationalist Party</a>, which joined the PLN coalition. In 1959 the former PREN faction, the faction of <a href="Alfredo%20Alem%C3%A1n">Alfredo Alemán</a> and the faction of <a href="Carlos%20Sucre%20Calvo">Carlos Sucre Calvo</a>, who was a faction leader in the CPN during <a href="Jos%C3%A9%20Antonio%20Rem%C3%B3n%20Cantera">Remón</a>'s tenure, left the CPN and registered as separate political parties (<a href="Renewal%20Party">Renewal Party</a>, <a href="DIPAL%20Party">DIPAL Party</a> and <a href="Progressive%20National%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Progressive National Party</a>).
In 1960 <a href="Ricardo%20Arias%20%28politician%29">Ricardo Arias</a>, the candidate of CPN, unsuccessfully ran in the presidential elections, obtaining only 85,981 votes (35.61%).
In 1963 former <a href="Popular%20Union%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Popular Union Party</a> faction, led by <a href="Bernardino%20Gonz%C3%A1lez%20Ru%C3%ADz">Bernardino González Ruíz</a>, left the CPN and registered as the <a href="Democratic%20Action%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Democratic Action Party</a>.
For the 1964 elections, the CPN was the main component of the <a href="National%20Opposition%20Alliance">National Opposition Alliance</a> (ANO), with the CPN's <a href="Juan%20de%20Arco%20Galindo">Juan de Arco Galindo</a> as the coalition's presidential candidate. He polled 47,753 votes (14.62%) and came third.
In 1968 CPN allied with the <a href="National%20Union%20%28Panama%29">National Union</a> (UN) and its candidate <a href="Arnulfo%20Arias">Arnulfo Arias</a>, the CPN polled only 19,072 votes (05.95%).
All political parties including the CPN were banned by <a href="Omar%20Torrijos">Omar Torrijos</a> after the military coup of 1968.
In 1981 the CPN joined the <a href="Third%20Nationalist%20Party">Third Nationalist Party</a>, <a href="National%20Liberation%20Movement%20%28Panama%29">National Liberation Movement</a> and factions that had earlier split off from <a href="National%20Liberal%20Party%20%28Panama%29">National Liberal Party</a> and <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28Panama%29">Republican Party</a> to form the opposition <a href="National%20Liberal%20Republican%20Movement%20%28Panama%29">National Liberal Republican Movement</a> (MOLIRENA).
